Inference: Soil moisture rising during rain detections and temperature drops indicates effective rainfall infiltration
Description: Rain cools the environment and increases soil moisture simultaneously, showing that water is reaching the soil surface and penetrating effectively.
short rationale: Shows field infiltration effectiveness; minor operational sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during rain detections with rising humidity indicates saturated atmospheric conditions supporting rainfall
Description: High humidity and rainfall together contribute significantly to soil moisture gain.
short rationale: Highlights favorable wet conditions; limited privacy impact.

Inference: Soil moisture falling during rain detections despite temperature drops indicates insufficient rainfall quantity
Description: Rain is present but too light to offset evaporative or percolation losses.
short rationale: Reveals inadequate rain events affecting irrigation needs.

Inference: Soil moisture stable during rain detections and rising humidity suggests canopy interception or poor infiltration
Description: Rain increases humidity but does not reach the soil due to vegetation or surface conditions.
short rationale: Points to infiltration barriers; modest operational exposure.

Inference: Soil moisture spiking during rain detections and low temperatures indicates efficient water retention under cool conditions
Description: Low heat prevents evaporation, allowing rainfall to maximize moisture gain.
short rationale: Shows conditions of high retention; low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during rain detections on high-temperature days indicates heavy or intense rainfall overcoming evaporative loss
Description: Only strong rainfall can increase moisture when temperatures are high.
short rationale: Signals intense rain events; minor operational detail.

Inference: Soil moisture falling during rain detections on high-temperature and low-humidity days indicates evaporative dominance
Description: Rain evaporates quickly before effectively hydrating the soil.
short rationale: Indicates inefficiency of rain under hot, dry air; modest impact.

Inference: Soil moisture rising after rain detections and humidity spikes indicate delayed soil infiltration from sustained rainfall
Description: Rainfall may take time to percolate into deeper soil layers where sensors are located.
short rationale: Shows delayed percolation; low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture falling after rain detections despite high humidity suggests rainfall was superficial or short-lived
Description: Rain increased humidity but did not provide enough water to improve soil moisture.
short rationale: Reveals superficial rain; limited privacy concern.

Inference: Soil moisture rising at night during rain detections and high humidity indicates dew contribution alongside rainfall
Description: Nighttime moisture forms from both precipitation and condensation.
short rationale: Night dew insight; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture falling at night despite rain detections indicates warm nighttime winds or soil hydrophobicity
Description: Moisture cannot accumulate due to environmental drying or infiltration issues.
short rationale: Suggests site-specific drying issues; modest exposure.

Inference: Soil moisture increasing during periods of no rain detections but high humidity indicates dew-driven hydration
Description: Humidity alone, especially in mornings or nights, can contribute measurable soil moisture.
short rationale: Dew contribution info; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture stable during high humidity and no rain detections indicates minimal atmospheric impact on soil hydration
Description: Humidity affects air conditions but not soil moisture in this scenario.
short rationale: Shows negligible effect; low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture falling during high humidity and no rain detections indicates deep soil drying unrelated to atmospheric moisture
Description: Deeper soil layers lose water even when air is moist.
short rationale: Indicates deeper drying trend; modest operational relevance.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during low humidity and rain detections indicates highly effective rainfall penetration
Description: Rainfall remains strong enough to hydrate soil even when dry air tries to evaporate it quickly.
short rationale: Shows robust rain events; limited privacy impact.

Inference: Soil moisture failing to rise during rain detections and falling temperatures suggests shallow rainfall unable to reach sensor depth
Description: Only surface-level wetting occurs, with deeper soil remaining dry.
short rationale: Highlights insufficient penetration; modest operational sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture spikes when rain detections occur during rapidly rising humidity indicate strong storm activity
Description: Sharp increases in humidity and rainfall signal sudden storm moisture being absorbed by the soil.
short rationale: Storm intensity indicator; low privacy risk.

Inference: Soil moisture declining steadily during long gaps between rain detections and rising temperatures indicate warm-season drought progression
Description: Increasing heat accelerates moisture loss without rainfall replenishment.
short rationale: Signals drought progression affecting field operations.

Inference: Soil moisture stable despite rising temperatures and no rain detections indicates strong soil retention capacity
Description: Soil maintains moisture even under drying atmospheric conditions.
short rationale: Shows soil retention quality; minor sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture falling despite stable temperatures and high humidity with no rain detections indicates internal soil drainage
Description: Soil loses moisture downward rather than through atmospheric evaporation.
short rationale: Points to drainage characteristics; modest exposure.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during rain detections and temperature stability suggests moderate rainfall without significant cooling
Description: Rainfall is present but not intense enough to alter temperature patterns noticeably.
short rationale: Basic rainfall effect; low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture increasing during rain detections and rapidly dropping temperatures indicates cold-front precipitation
Description: Cool air masses bring rainfall and reduce temperatures sharply.
short rationale: Identifies cold-front rain; limited operational sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture increasing while humidity drops during rain detections suggests warm rainfall with evaporative cooling
Description: Raindrops evaporate mid-air, lowering humidity slightly while still contributing to soil moisture.
short rationale: Shows warm rain dynamics; minor sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture decreasing while humidity rises during rain detections signals wind-caused redistribution of rain
Description: Moisture may be blown away from the soil surface or prevented from reaching deeper layers.
short rationale: Indicates wind-driven loss; modest operational info.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during multiple rain detections and early-morning humidity peaks indicates diurnal rainfall patterns
Description: Rainfall and humidity peaks at dawn combine to hydrate soil strongly.
short rationale: Reveals diurnal rain pattern; low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture rising more strongly during nighttime rain detections than daytime detections indicates reduced evaporation in dark hours
Description: Lower temperatures at night maximize moisture retention.
short rationale: Highlights night advantage; minimal privacy impact.

Inference: Soil moisture plateauing at high levels despite multiple rain detections and cool weather indicates soil saturation
Description: The soil cannot hold additional water, even under ideal wet conditions.
short rationale: Shows saturation state; modest operational sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture plateauing at low levels despite rain detections and high humidity indicates severe soil hydrophobicity or compaction
Description: Water cannot penetrate efficiently despite favorable atmospheric signals.
short rationale: Signals problematic soil condition impacting management.

Inference: Soil moisture rises occurring only when both rain detections and high humidity coincide indicate dual-condition infiltration dependency
Description: Rain alone or humidity alone is insufficient; both are needed for soil moisture gain.
short rationale: Shows dependency on combined conditions; low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture fails to rise when rain detections occur but humidity stays low, indicating evaporative rainfall loss
Description: Dry air accelerates raindrop evaporation, reducing soil infiltration.
short rationale: Indicates evaporative losses; modest operational detail.

Inference: Soil moisture increases during falling humidity and rain detections indicate rainfall heavy enough to suppress atmospheric drying
Description: Rainfall volume overcomes humidity decline to hydrate soil effectively.
short rationale: Shows strong rain overcoming drying; low sensitivity.
